com.hopding.noidmat

Class Player

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.hopding.noidmat.Player

  • public class Player
extends java.lang.Object
    The Player class represents a user's Minecraft player. It complies with the Singleton design pattern, meaning there is only one instance per jvm, and therefore per running Minecraft instance.

    A reference to the single Player instance can be obtained with the following code: 

    
 Player player = Player.getPlayer();
    The user's Minecraft player can be controlled with the Player class by calling the various methods it contains. It is important that these methods not be called within the Minecraft game threads. They should be called inside a separate thread. The recommended way of doing this is to extend the abstract class Task and implement its run(Player, String...) method by calling methods on the passed in Player instance. A reference to the Task subclass can then be passed into the runTask(Task, String...) method to be run. The user's Minecraft player will then respond to the methods called in the Task subclass's run(Player, String...) method.
    Author:
    Andrew Dillon

      • onClientTick

        public void onClientTick(net.minecraftforge.fml.common.gameevent.TickEvent.ClientTickEvent event)
        Used by Forge, should NOT be called otherwise. Called on every tick of the client. Should never ever be called except by Forge.

      • setKeyboardLock

        public void setKeyboardLock(boolean lock)
        Sets the keyboard lock. When the keyboard lock is set to true, the user cannot use the keyboard to interact with the game. The only key the user can press is ESC, which will cause all mouse and keyboard locks to be set to false. It will also end whatever Task the player is currently running, if any. It is advised to lock the keyboard at the beginning of a Task, to prevent the user from disrupting the Task.
        Parameters:
        lock - a boolean specifying whether to lock or unlock keyboard input to the game

      • isKeyboardLocked

        public boolean isKeyboardLocked()
        Returns the state of the keyboard lock, true if keyboard input is locked, false if it is not.
        Returns:
        a boolean indicating the state of the keyboard lock

      • setMousePosLock

        public void setMousePosLock(boolean lock)
        Sets the mouse position lock. When the mouse position lock is set to true, the user cannot move the mouse to interact with the game. It is advised to lock the mouse position at the beginning of a Task, to prevent the user from disrupting the Task.
        Parameters:
        lock - a boolean specifying whether to lock or unlock mouse position input to the game
        Known Bugs:
        The mouse lock can be temporarily subverted if the mouse is moved soon after the Player's pitch or yaw is changed.

      • isMousePosLocked

        public boolean isMousePosLocked()
        Returns the state of the mouse position lock, true if the mouse position is locked, false if it is not.
        Returns:
        a boolean indicating the state of the mouse position lock

      • setMouseButtonsLock

        public void setMouseButtonsLock(boolean lock)
        Sets the mouse button lock. When the mouse button lock is set to true, the user cannot use the mouse buttons to interact with the game. It is advised to lock the mouse position at the beginning of a Task, to prevent the user from disrupting the Task.
        Parameters:
        lock - a boolean specifying whether to lock or unlock mouse button input to the game

      • areMouseButtonsLocked

        public boolean areMouseButtonsLocked()
        Returns the state of the mouse button lock, true if the mouse buttons are locked, false if they are not.
        Returns:
        a boolean indicating the state of the mouse button lock.

      • cancelAction

        public void cancelAction()
        Cancels the action currently being executed by the Player and sets all keys to not pressed. An action corresponds to a single method in the Player class.

        If a Task is still being executed, calling cancelAction() will NOT stop it. Calling cancelAction() only stops a single action within the larger Task. To stop a Task, invoke TaskRunner.stopCurrentTask().

      • lookAtFootLevelBlock

        public boolean lookAtFootLevelBlock()
                             throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Causes the player to look at the block at foot level just in front of the player, if one exists. If there is no block at foot level in front of the player, the method returns false and the player doesn't move.
        Returns:
        true if the action was successful, false if no such block exists
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • lookAtGroundLevelBlock

        public boolean lookAtGroundLevelBlock()
                               throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Causes the player to look at the block at ground level just in front of the player, if one exists. If there is no block at ground level in front of the player, the method returns false and the player doesn't move.
        Returns:
        true if the action was successful, false if no such block exists
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException
        Note:
        The method is unlikely to return if it is called while a block exists that is at foot level directly in front of the player. It is advised to call lookAtFootLevelBlock() before calling lookAtGroundLevelBlock() to avoid this issue, e.g.: 
        
 //This code will break any blocks at foot level and
 //then look at the ground level block, if one exists
 if(player.lookAtFootLevelBlock())
 	player.breakBlock();
 player.lookAtGroundLevelBlock();
        or 
        
 //This code will cause the player to place a block at foot level
 //on top of the ground level block in front of the player, even
 //if there is snow or tallgrass in the way
 if(!player.lookAtFootLevelBlock())
 	player.lookAtGroundLevelBlock();
 player.placeBlock();

      • breakBlock

        public void breakBlock()
                throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Causes the player to begin breaking whatever block is currently being looked at. Once the block is broken, the method will return. The player will use whatever tool is currently selected in the hot bar to break the block, regardless of whether or not that is the ideal tool for breaking the block (e.g. iron pick for a diamond block, a shovel for dirt, etc...).
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • placeBlock

        public void placeBlock(boolean autoScroll)
                throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Causes the player to attempt placing whatever (block, item, etc...) is currently selected in the hot bar. Once the player has attempted to place the item/block, the method will return.

        The autoScroll param indicates whether or not to autoscroll. If autoScroll is set to true, and placeBlock() is going to place the last item in the currently selected stack, then after placing that item, the currently selected hotbar slot will search the hot bar from left to right for another stack of the same item type. If no stacks of the same type are found, then the selected hot bar slot will not change. Otherwise, the player's selected hotbar slot will change to the newly found item stack.

        Parameters:
        autoScroll - a boolean indicating whether this invocation of placeBlock() should autoscroll
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • placeBlock

        public void placeBlock()
                throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Causes the player to attempt placing whatever (block, item, etc...) is currently selected in the hot bar. Once the player has attempted to place the item/block, the method will return.
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • placeBlockBelow

        public void placeBlockBelow(boolean autoScroll)
                     throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Causes the player to jump and attempt placing the item currently selected in the hot bar directly below. When placeBlockBelow() returns, the player will still be looking at the same place that was being viewed immediately prior to calling placeBlockBelow().

        The autoScroll param indicates whether or not to autoscroll. If autoScroll is set to true, and placeBlockBelow() is going to place the last item in the currently selected stack, then after placing that item, the currently selected hotbar slot will search the hot bar from left to right for another stack of the same item type. If no stacks of the same type are found, then the selected hot bar slot will not change. Otherwise, the player's selected hotbar slot will change to the newly found item stack.

        Parameters:
        autoScroll - a boolean indicating whether this invocation of placeBlockBelow() should autoscroll
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • placeBlockBelow

        public void placeBlockBelow()
                     throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Causes the player to jump and attempt placing the item currently selected in the hot bar directly below. When placeBlockBelow() returns, the player will still be looking at the same place that was being viewed immediately prior to calling placeBlockBelow().
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • selectHotbarSlot

        public void selectHotbarSlot(int slotNum)
                      throws OutOfRangeException
        Changes the selected hot bar slot (1-9). The slotNum arg specifies the slot to be selected. 1 will select the slot farthest to the left. Successively larger values will select slots farther to the right, 9 being the far right slot.
        Parameters:
        slotNum - an int specifying the slot to be selected
        Throws:
        OutOfRangeException - if the slotNum arg value is out of the range 1-9

      • getHotbarSlot

        public int getHotbarSlot()
        Gets the index of the hotbar slot that's currently selected. A return value of 1 indicates the slot farthest to the left is selected. Successively larger values indicate slots farther to the right, 9 being the far right slot.
        Returns:
        an int indicating the index of the currently selected hotbar slot.

      • getNumItemsLeft

        public int getNumItemsLeft()
        Gets the size of the item stack currently held by the player.
        Returns:
        an int indicating the number of items left in the stack held by the player.

      • swing

        public void swing()
        Causes the player to swing the item currently selected in the hot bar one time. Calling swing() multiple times will not break items or blocks, it is usually only used to attack entities (mobs or players).

      • walkForward

        public void walkForward(int walkDistance)
                 throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Causes the player to walk forward the specified number of blocks. Before the player begins to move, the player's yaw will be adjusted so that the player is looking straight ahead (0, 90, 180, or 270 degrees). walkForward(int) does not compensate for potential obstacles in the player's path. If the player is knocked off course (e.g. by a skeleton's arrow), the method may fail to properly execute and/or return.
        Parameters:
        walkDistance - an int specifying the number of blocks the player should walk forward
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • walkBackward

        public void walkBackward(int walkDistance)
                  throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Causes the player to walk backwards the specified number of blocks. Before the player begins to move, the player's yaw will be adjusted so that the player is looking straight ahead (0, 90, 180, or 270 degrees). walkBackward(int) does not compensate for potential obstacles in the player's path. If the player is knocked off course (e.g. by a skeleton's arrow), the method may fail to properly execute and/or return.
        Parameters:
        walkDistance - an int specifying the number of blocks the player should walk backward
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • setYaw

        public void setYaw(float degree)
        Sets the player's yaw - the direction the player is facing left and right.
        Parameters:
        degree - a float specifying the desired yaw

      • getYaw

        public float getYaw()
        Gets the current yaw of the player - the direction the player is facing left and right. The float value returned by getYaw() will always be within the range 0-360.
        Returns:
        the player's current yaw as a float

      • setPitch

        public void setPitch(float degree)
              throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Sets the player's pitch - the angle the player is facing up and down.
        A degree arg value of 90 will cause the player to look straight down.
        A degree arg value of -90 will cause the player to look straight up.
        A degree arg value of 0 will cause the player to look straight ahead.
        Any value is valid for the degree arg, but if the value if not in the range -90 to 90, then it will be clipped such that it is within that range. Values < -90 will be regarded as -90. Values > 90 will be regarded as 90.
        Parameters:
        degree - a float value specifying the desired pitch
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • getPitch

        public float getPitch()
        Gets the player's current pitch - the angle the player is facing up and down. The pitch value will always be within the range -90 to 90.
        Returns:
        the player's current pitch as a float

      • straightenYaw

        public void straightenYaw()
                   throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Straightens out the player's yaw. Upon returning, the player's yaw will be one of four different values, depending on what the player's yaw was prior to calling straightenYaw():
        0, if the player's yaw was in the range 315-360.
        90, if the player's yaw was in the range 45-135.
        180, if the player's yaw was in the range 135-225.
        270, if the player's yaw was in the range 225-315.
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • aboutFace

        public void aboutFace()
        Causes the player to turn around, increasing the player's yaw by 180.

      • turnRight

        public void turnRight()
        Causes the player to turn right, increasing the player's yaw by 90.

      • turnLeft

        public void turnLeft()
        Causes the player to turn left, decreasing the player's yaw by 90.

      • isInFrontOfPit

        public boolean isInFrontOfPit()
                       throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Detects whether or there is a block at ground level directly in front of the player. If there is, then isInFrontOfPit() returns false. If there isn't, then isInFrontOfPit() returns true.
        Returns:
        boolean indicating the presence of a block at ground level in front of the player
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException

      • pause

        public void pause(int millis)
           throws java.lang.InterruptedException
        Causes the player to pause for the specified number of milliseconds.
        Parameters:
        millis - an int specifying the number of milliseconds to pause for
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException
